item.title: Calculus - Integral
item.description:
Technique

WHY: Why we use techniques to solve the integral problems?

  • The function cannot be antiderivatived directly.
  • The process of original function to integral is too challenging.
  • Direct integral cannot give us the answer.

WHAT: What is the techniques of integral

  • It could turn one function which cannot or is challenging to integral to a simple function
  • The tricks that we can use in the process of integral.

HOW: How to use the techniques to integral

If the function combines with its derivative: Substitution

Rules: $\frac{df}{dx} = \frac{df}{dh} \cdot \frac{dh}{dx}$

  • $\int{F’(g(x)) \cdot g’(x)}{dx}$

$$ u = g(x), du = g’(x) dx \rArr \int{F’(u)}{du} = F(u) + C = F(g(x)) + C $$

  • $\int{\tan{x}}{dx}$

$$ \int{\tan{x}}{dx} = \int{\frac{\sin{x}}{\cos{x}}}{dx} $$ $$ u = \cos{x}, du = -\sin{x} dx \rArr \int{\frac{-du}{u}} = - \ln{u} + c = -\ln{\cos{x}} + C $$

  • $\int{\frac{1}{x(x^2 + 1)}}{dx}$

$$ u = \arctan{x}, du = \frac{1}{x^2 + 1}dx, x = \tan{u} \rArr \int{\frac{1}{\tan{u}}}{du} $$ $$ v = \sin{u}, dv = \cos{u}du \rArr \int{\frac{1}{v}}{dv} = \ln{v} + C = \ln{\sin{u}} + C = \ln{\sin{\arctan{x}} + C} $$

  • $\int{\sec^4{x} \tan^3{x}}{dx}$ ($\tan{\theta} = \sec^2{\theta} - 1 = \int\sec^2{\theta}$)

$$ \sec^2{x} = \tan^2{x} + 1 $$ $$ \tan’(x) = \sec^2(x) $$ $$ u = \sqrt{16 + 3x}, u^2 = 16 + 3x \in (4^2, 8^2), 2udu = 3dx $$ $$ \frac{(u^2 - 16)2}{9}du = \frac{\frac{2}{3}u^3 - 32u}{9} = \frac{2u^3 - 3*32u}{27} = \frac{8 * 128 - 6 * 128 - 128 + 3 * 128}{27} $$

If the function combines with a simple function’s derivative: Int by part

  • $\int{x \cdot \sin x}dx$: reduce power
  • $\int{\ln x}dx$: eliminate \ln(x) (multiply with 1)
  • $\int{x \cdot \arctan x}dx$
  • $\int{\arcsin x \cdot \ln x}dx$

Other techniques (Not belongs to Integral)

Partial Fractions

$$ f(x) = \frac{A(x)}{B(x)} = f_1(x) + \frac{C(x)}{D(x)}, deg(A) >= deg(B) \ or \ deg(C) < deg(D) $$ $$ f(x) = \frac{C(x)}{D(x)} \rArr D(x) = (a_1x+b_1)^{p_1}…(a_ix+b_i)^{p_i}(u_1x^2 + v_1x + w_1)^{r_1}…(u_jx^2 + v_jx + w_j)^{r_j} $$ $$ \rArr \sum_{i, k}\frac{C_{i, k}}{(a_ix+b_i)^{p_k}} + \sum_{j, h}\frac{g_{j, h}x + h_{j, h}}{(u_jx^2 + v_jx + w_j)^{r_h}} $$

Approx to limit

item.title: Calculus - Differentiate
item.description:
WHY

Why should we learn differentiation?

Find the rate: At (when), the rate at which (how) is increasing/decreasing by (what) (unit).

  • Analyzing function $f(x)$ is increasing/decreasing/constant on $(a, b)$
  • Analyzing points ($x = a$)
    • Critical point: $f’(x) = 0$ or $\nexists f’(x)$
    • Stationary point: $f’(x) = 0$
    • Relative/Local Extrema: $f’(x) = 0$ and $f’’(x) \neq 0$
    • Inflected point: $f’’(x) = 0$ - concave upward(>0)/downward(<0)

Why a function could be differentiated? - Differentiability

  • Limit

  • Continuous: $\lim_{x \rarr a}{f(x)} = f(a)$ ($\lim_{x \rarr a}{f(x)} = \lim_{x \rarr a^+}{f(x)} = \lim_{x \rarr a^-}{f(x)}$)

    • IVT (Intermediate Value Theorem): If $f(x)$ is continuous on $[a, b]$, then $\exist c \in [a,b], f(c) \in [f(a), f(b)]$
      • MVT (Mean Value Theorem): If $f(x)$ is differentiable on $[a, b]$, then $\exist c, f’(c) = \frac{f(b) - f(a)}{b - a}$
      • EVT (Extreme Value Theorem): If $f(x)$ is continuous on closed interval $[a, b]$, then $\exist c_1, c_2, f_{max}(x) = f(c_1), f_{min}(x) = f(c_2)$
    • Discontinuous points (Discontinuity)
      • Removable ~: $\lim_{x \rarr a}f(x) \neq f(a)$
      • Jump ~: $\lim_{x \rarr a+}f(x) \neq \lim_{x \rarr a-}f(x)$
      • Infinite (Essential) ~: $\lim_{x \rarr a^+}f(x)$ or $\lim_{x \rarr a^-}f(x)$ equals $\pm \infin$

  • Smooth: $\lim_{c \rarr 0^+}{\frac{f(a + c) - f(c)}{c}} = \lim_{c \rarr 0^-}{\frac{f(a + c) - f(c)}{c}}$

WHAT: Difference between differentiate and derivative

  • $\frac{dy}{dx}$ differentiate is a method to cut source function to know the tendency
  • $y’(x)$ derivative is that kinds of tendency.
